content.webTitle: Thomas Cook proves there's still life in package holidays

fields.headline: Thomas Cook proves there's still life in package holidays
fields.bodyText: That's quite a trick: announce a hefty two-for-five rights issue while simultaneously asking the market to consume a placing of shares, and yet see the share price rise 13%. The company is Thomas Cook. Obituaries were being prepared 18 months ago as a debt crisis threatened to become overwhelming, but these days the package holiday firm is everybody's favourite recovery stock. It has travelled from 16p to 164p in less than a year under new chief executive Harriet Green, who has surprised herself with the savings she has found. She announced another £40m yesterday, meaning her target for "cost out" and profit improvement by the end of 2015 has increased from £350m to £390m. Outsiders suspected unlamented former boss Manny Fontenla-Novoa had assembled a disjointed and inefficient travel empire. Few knew a hard-headed newcomer could cut so much cost so quickly. The other reason for the shares' popularity yesterday is the fund-raising itself. There's a €525m bond issue alongside the £120m placing and £305m rights issue. That collection will remove the lingering risk that the tower of debt (£1.2bn at the end of March) could undo Green's operational handiwork. Suddenly, the capital structure looks vaguely normal again and there's a new £691m borrowing facility to ride the inevitable cash swings in this seasonal industry. Big long-term challenges remain. The force is still with easyJet, expedia, Ryanair and DIY holidays. Strikes by air traffic controllers will occur and aviation fuel prices will bounce around. But a properly managed Thomas Cook should still be able to prosper in this world. The package holiday is not dead and gross margins in the UK – the most troublesome division – are 23%. Group turnover is £9bn. If costs and debt are under control, the business works.
